what defines a functional language and then something you said which rang
really true with me is that it might make more sense to say what features
support a functional programming style like what what features do you think a language needs in order to support
functional programming yeah great questions yeah so so when we talk about what is a
functional language um the way I think about a functional language is a language that supports Works functional programming uh where if we understand
functional programming uh there's a couple of different ways to think about it the way I usually think about it is programming with only pure functions so
pure functions being functions that take inputs and produce output so they take
in arguments and they return a return value and that is all they do they don't have any other side effects so they're
not changing anything else in the world or in the program except returning their
return value um another way people often think about it is programming without state so instead of having values change
over time in your program and thinking about what the values are at any given moment and how they need to change given
things happening in the world um is thinking about it in terms of data transformation in terms of data coming
in and data going out and uh there is really only the process of turning that
in data to that out data and not any other kind of work to be done not any other state to be changed so um regard
regardless of of how you choose to to think about functional programming then a functional language is as you say you
know one that supports doing that so you've got your pure functional languages which completely constrain you
to working in that functional Paradigm so you are not allowed to have impure
functions you are not allowed to have State uh in your in your programs um in a pure functional language and then you
have what we could think of as uh multi-paradigm languages where you can
do fun functional programming if you would like to and um it has features that support that like for example you
need first class function so you need to be able to um take functions and treat
them as uh as as any kind of data that you would have as strings or booleans or
what have you so you can take them as inputs to other functions you can return them as outputs they're just kind of
items in the world that you can work with um so having first class functions is really important um sometimes having
uh certain utilities can make things really easy like being able to do things like mapping and filtering over um
arrays or collections of data instead of having to use for Loops or while Loops to do kind of stateful iteration um so
these types of features if a language has them but doesn't necessarily force you to use them then we could still
think of it as a functional language because you can program functionally in it so I'm thinking of languages like JavaScript or python or um Scala or F or
these languages where you can choose to work in a functional language they often have nice things like um like Anonymous
functions like Lambda functions things like that that make it really easy to um to to work in a functional style but you
can also do things more imperatively if you would like at times so um I think in
terms of these languages that that support multiple paradigms that's always a really great thing to my mind because
it allows you to kind of choose the right tool for the job however a lot of people um that are that are working on
problems that are especially well-framed as data transformation problems uh are a
huge fan of just working in pure functional languages so not only do I have the features I need to do
functional programming but also the language is keeping me honest it's keeping me from needing to discipline
myself to write my code functionally it's doing the discipline for me and and
I don't have to worry about it and I do actually like that because uh then I don't have to you know kind of uh keep
tabs on myself and make sure that I am using the more functional features and not ending up veering towards more
imperative style um so pure functional languages are great for that because I would say they have this added feature
of uh you have no choice added feature of you are enforcing yourself um to to
live by the functional worldview as it were yeah that we I I I think personally

um so what what what what do I think is what are some of the benefits of
programming in a functional way do you think so for me I think the main thing
is uh predictability it's uh it is so hard in a stateful imperative program to
know exactly what the world is going to look like when you run this code so you
can have your tests you can say all right if the world looks like this and this and this and this then does this
run correctly you can think about all of those edge cases as your program and you can think about you know okay what if
what if that thing is undefined or what if this thing is uh you know a different size than I was expecting it to be um
but you have to do all of that work to think about all of those ways that the world can be and you're never going to do it perfectly you're never going to
think about everything and your test Suite is never going to capture all of the different configurations the world
can be in and so if your program is stateful and depends on that um then
you're going to have bugs right and you're going to not be able to predict what your program is going to do in any in a certain given situation so in
functional programming because every function is kind of simple in a way way
in the sense that it takes inputs and it gives you an output and if you give it the same input it's always going to give
you the same output um it becomes very predictable it becomes very easy to know
okay if I if these are my inputs this is what my output is going to be so that becomes easy to test it becomes easy to
um kind of enforce in in some functional languages that enforce things like strict typing you can already know that
like it's not going to be undefined because that's just that's not ever going to happen in this case because my
type system has made sure of that um and you can you can essentially you can narrow it narrow down what you need to
think about to this this one function you can test this one function you can um think about the performance of this
one function and you can know that no matter what else is going on in the world these are the inputs it's going to
get this is the output it's going to give and that's predictable that's not going to change because it doesn't depend on any state so the consequences
for you know debugging for testing for um maintaining for changing refactoring
code are just amazing there because if I know what the inputs uh what the outputs
are supposed to be for any given input then I can take this one little modular function out I can replace it with
another one that's more performant or easier to read or whatever what have you
um so much more easily and I can predict the types of bugs I'm going to um encounter I can make sure I'm handling
